tutorial.title: How to access one HTML element
tutorial.descriptionContent: Learn how to access one HTML element to store it in JS,

lessons.title: Storing
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've already seen that we can use JavaScript variables, like element here, to store HTML elements.

Make sure to pick const, followed by element.

lessons.title: getElementById
lessons.interactiveContent:
And we saw that we can use getElementById to access the HTML element with the messages id.

Make sure to pick document, followed by .getElementById, and finally ("messages");.

lessons.title: Accessing through Variable
lessons.interactiveContent:
But let's practice that a bit more! We can access the text of the paragraph through the variable name, with .innerHTML.

Make sure to pick element, followed by ., and finally innerHTML.

lessons.title: Setting through Variable
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use the variable to update the paragraph's content, by adding = and the new value "No Messages".

Make sure to pick element followed by . and then innerHTML, =, "No Messages".

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we store the element we're accessing through document.getElementById()?

Using a variableWe can't store it since it's not a value

Using a variable.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which element does the type variable contain?

The p elementThe h3 element

The p element.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this code display in the console?

SoundClouddocument.getElementById("platform")

Make sure to pick SoundCloud.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's the text of the h2 element when the webpage displays?

"Turntable Tracks""The Turntable"

"Turntable Tracks".

lessons.title: Example 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create a variable to store the ul element.

Make sure to pick priceList followed by = and then document, ., getElementById, (, "prices", ).

lessons.title: Example 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Save the heading into the variable by assembling the code.

Make sure to pick title =, followed by document, and finally .getElementById("reviews");.

lessons.title: Example 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
Display the paragraph's text by assembling the code inside the display statement.

Make sure to pick lyrics, followed by ., and finally innerHTML =.

lessons.title: Example 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Update the shop's name using the title variable and the .innerHTML instruction.

Make sure to pick title, followed by ., and finally innerHTML.

lessons.title: Intro
lessons.interactiveContent: We've seen how to use id to query HTML elements. But what if the element doesn't have an id? Let's learn how to query specific selectors.

lessons.title: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to retrieve an individual HTML element, we can use the querySelector() method from document.

Make sure to pick querySelector.

lessons.title: Paragraph
lessons.interactiveContent:
To select a specific element, we add a selector inside parentheses. We can use an HTML tag, like the p tag if we want to get the paragraph.

Make sure to pick p.

lessons.title: Change content
lessons.interactiveContent:
Once we've stored the element in a variable, we can change it. Here, we're using the innerHTML property to change its content.

Complete the code and press the button to see that querySelector also works!

Make sure to pick el followed by . and then innerHTML, =.

lessons.title: ID
lessons.interactiveContent:
querySelector() works with all selectors, like tags, classes, and ID's. If we're looking for an ID, we add the # at the beginning.

Make sure to pick #, followed by prompt.

lessons.title: Class
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we're looking for a class, we have to add . at the beginning.

Make sure to pick ., followed by prompt.

lessons.title: First result
lessons.interactiveContent:
querySelector() only retrieves the first element it finds.

So, if we have two elements with the same tag or class, we only access the first one.

Make sure to pick <h3>, followed by First Heading, and finally </h3>.

lessons.title: Question: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the querySelector() method access?

Only the first HTML element that matches its searchAll HTML elements that match its search

Only the first HTML element that matches its search.

lessons.title: Question: Change content
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which h3 element does the refresh() function change?

The first h3 elementThe second h3 element

The first h3 element.

lessons.title: Question: ID
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which h3 element does the refresh() function change?

The one with the sports IDThe first h3 element

The one with the sports ID.

lessons.title: Question: ID
lessons.interactiveContent:
What selectors does the querySelector() method work with?

Any selectors, including tags, classes, or ID'sIt only works with tags or ID

Any selectors, including tags, classes, or ID's.

lessons.title: Question: Class
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code where we're trying to access an element with a specific class?

The . is missing from the class selectorThe # is missing from the class selector

The . is missing from the class selector.

lessons.title: Example: QuerySelector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code querySelector() as a method for document.

Make sure to pick document followed by . and then querySelector, (, ).

lessons.title: Example: Paragraph
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the selector for the p element inside parentheses.

Make sure to pick ", followed by p, and finally ".

lessons.title: Example: ID
lessons.interactiveContent:
Use the querySelector to access the element with the #update ID.

Make sure to type #update.

lessons.title: Example: Class
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the .sport class.

Make sure to pick ., followed by sport.

lessons.title: Example: First result
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the selector to change the text of the second h3 element.

Make sure to pick ., followed by tech.

lessons.title: Classes
lessons.interactiveContent:
We know querySelector() gets the first element it finds. That can be a problem if the element we're looking for comes later in the code.

Code .prompt and then press the button to see how only the first element with that class changes.

Make sure to pick ., followed by prompt.

lessons.title: Tag and class
lessons.interactiveContent:
If several elements share a class, like .prompt here, we can specify its tag.

We specify p.prompt inside parentheses to select the paragraph with the .prompt class.

Make sure to pick p, followed by ., and finally prompt.

lessons.title: Second class
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also look for an element that has multiple classes. Before we can see that work, add the class name update to the second paragraph.

Make sure to type update.

lessons.title: Second class II
lessons.interactiveContent:
To access an element with two classes, we include them together. Here, it's .prompt.update or .update.prompt .

Now we don't need to specify the HTML tag because there's only one element with those two classes.

Make sure to pick ., followed by update.

lessons.title: Outro
lessons.interactiveContent:
querySelector is very powerful and we can use it to access any specific element on a webpage.

Make sure to pick querySelector followed by ( and then ".order.info", ).

lessons.title: Question: Tag and class
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code if we want to access a p element of class prompt?

It should be p.promptIt should be p#prompt

It should be p.prompt.

lessons.title: Question: Second class
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we select an element with multiple classes?

One class name after another with a . before eachOne class after another with a space in between

One class name after another with a . before each.

lessons.title: Question: Second class II
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which p element does the querySelector() method access?

The third p elementThe second p element

The third p element.

lessons.title: Question: Outro
lessons.interactiveContent:
When do we use the querySelector() method?

Anytime we want to access elements with specific selectorsWe only use it when an element doesn't have an ID

Anytime we want to access elements with specific selectors.

lessons.title: Example: Classes
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code the .tech selector to access the right element.

Make sure to pick ., followed by tech.

lessons.title: Example: Tag and class
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code p.copyright to change the text of the last paragraph.

Make sure to pick p, followed by ., and finally copyright.

lessons.title: Example: Second class
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the paragraph element by coding p.tech.

Make sure to type p.tech.

lessons.title: Example: Second class II
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the paragraph element by coding the p.update.tech.

Make sure to pick p followed by . and then update, ., tech.
